data.tweet:
Don't build a product.

Build a portfolio of small bets.

Once you adopt this perspective, you become detached from the individual outcomes of your activities. Deciding what to do (and not to do) becomes a lot easier.

replies.tweet: @dvassallo Similar to what @levelsio does ? By creating small products and launching them early in the market ?

user.name: Sagar Jani
user.description: Problem solver | Interested in tech & entrepreneurship | Software engineer at Dius (views are my own)

answer.tweet: @sagarjani @levelsio Yep, @levelsio is the OG of this. @searchbound too.

replies.tweet: @dvassallo When do you decide that one product is big enough to launch the next one? Not talking about Info products here but SaaS.

user.name: Sumit Kumar
user.description: Maker of tresor.one, geoman.io and sharing the journey here. (Also Head of Engineering @sharenow_global) Part-time adult.

answer.tweet: @TweetsOfSumit Ideally, you want to never be forced to give up on an activity just so that you can try something new. Of course, you'll always have to option to stop doing those things that are not working out, but you'd want to be able to defer that decision to any time in the future.

data.tweet: You can hear my elaborate take on this topic on the @IndieHackers podcast:

linkWithImage.title: #177 ‚Äì Mastering the Lifestyle-First Approach to Indie Hacking with Daniel Vassallo | Indie Hackers | Episode 177
linkWithImage.description: When Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo) quit his job to become an indie hacker, he was making over $500,000 per year. It could have been a disastrous choice. Instead, less than two years later, he's built a suite of products that most founders would envy. In this episode we discuss how Daniel minimizes risk by running multiple projects simultaneously, how he turns time into a friend instead of an enemy by lowering his costs, and how a lifestyle-first business mindset can make you both richer and happier.

answer.tweet:
@ChaseRaz Yes, knowledge always has value, and acquiring knowledge always has a cost.

I'm pointing out that *on average*, it seems like the cost of acquiring knowledge from a degree is not paying off, since people are struggling to recoup their financial investment, let alone their time.

data.tweet:
Punished by Rewards ‚Äî People hate being controlled with carrots & sticks, and only intrinsic motivation lasts.

Man's Search for Meaning ‚Äî A good life is a story you're proud of.

4 Hour Work Week ‚Äî Design your lifestyle based on your preferences, not on preferences of others.

Unconditional Parenting ‚Äî Be on your child's side, unconditionally, all the time.

Blue Ocean Strategy ‚Äî Find uncontested markets.

Alchemy ‚Äî Rational is what works, not what makes sense.

Rework ‚Äî Constraints are advantages in disguise.

Hell Yeah or No ‚Äî Do almost nothing.

replies.tweet:
@dvassallo What's your thoughts on this?

Someone told me "Blue oceans don't stay blue for very long"

Competitors jump into new methods fairly fast negating any blue ocean you find.

user.description: Blessed to be a Dad with 9 kids.  Decentralized is better than smaller. Phenomenology is the best epistomology. To thrive, you must first survive.

data.tweet:

Black Swan ‚Äî Almost all consequential events are unpredictable.

Antifragile ‚Äî Some things benefit from shocks & variations, and you can be like that too.

Skin in the Game ‚Äî Risk exposure makes you smarter.
